title: R40074
content: In the early 1990s, most governments in the region transitioned to civilian democracies and embraced economic liberalization. President Clinton organized the first Summit of the Americas in Miami in 1994, attended by all democratically elected leaders except Fidel Castro. The leaders approved a Plan of Action with initiatives focused on democracy, economic integration, poverty eradication, and sustainable development. The Miami Summit in 1994 focused on economic integration, free trade, poverty eradication, and sustainable development in the hemisphere. Subsequent Summits introduced new initiatives like the creation of the Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA) by 2005. Special Summits in Bolivia, Chile, and Canada furthered discussions on environmental issues, education, democracy, and the FTAA. The Summit of the Americas process, institutionalized by the Organization of American States (OAS), has seen various summits in different countries like Canada, Mexico, and Argentina. These summits have focused on democracy, economic integration, and trade agreements like the Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA). President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela played a significant role in the discussions, particularly regarding the FTAA negotiations. In November 2005, the Summit of the Americas in Mar del Plata, Argentina, focused on creating jobs, fighting poverty, and democratic governance. President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela led opposition to the Bush Administration's proposal to resume FTAA negotiations. Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, and Paraguay from Mercosur also opposed the talks, citing issues with U.S. agricultural subsidies and preferring to wait until after the WTO's Doha Development Round for a more balanced agreement. Despite consensus from most countries, dissenting nations' economic influence effectively ended the FTAA negotiations. The Summit of the Americas in Mar del Plata, Argentina, focused on jobs, poverty, and governance. President Hugo Chávez opposed FTAA negotiations, leading to their end due to economic influence. The Inter-American Democratic Charter affirms democracy in the region and has been invoked during challenges. The Summits also led to economic initiatives like the Declaration of Nuevo León committing to reducing barriers. The Summits of the Americas have resulted in significant political and economic changes, such as the removal of leaders like Hugo Chávez in 2002 and Lucio Guttierez in 2005. Economic initiatives include reducing remittance transfer costs by 50% by 2008, leading to a decrease from 15% to 5.6% between 2000 and 2006. The United States has played a key role in reducing costs by promoting competition and new technology. Social programs like providing anti-retroviral therapy to 600,000 people with HIV/AIDS were also established. The Summits of the Americas led to successful social programs, including providing anti-retroviral therapy to over 640,000 people with HIV/AIDS by 2005. Funding from various initiatives like PEPFAR and the Global Fund contributed to this achievement. The U.S. government also supported HIV testing for over 400,000 individuals and invested over $552 million in HIV/AIDS programs in the region between 2001 and 2007. Despite these accomplishments, the Summits faced criticism for lacking transparency and openness according to civil society and anti-globalization organizations. The Summits of the Americas have faced criticism for lacking transparency and openness, with civil society groups arguing that important discussions should not be held behind closed doors. Some believe the Summits promote corporate power over social welfare, environmental protection, and citizens' rights. Despite agreements for openness and transparency, little has been done to increase civil society participation. Critics also point out that the Summits produce ambitious documents without effectively implementing previous commitments, with over 600 initiatives introduced since the first Summit. The Summits of the Americas have been criticized for producing ambitious documents with new initiatives but lacking in implementation and enforcement mechanisms. Over 600 initiatives have been introduced since the first Summit, but many have not been met due to countries' lack of capacity, will, and resources. This has raised doubts about the effectiveness and credibility of the Summit process in achieving tangible results in the hemisphere. Some analysts question the worth of continuing the Summit of the Americas process. The Summit of the Americas process, initiated in 1994, is being questioned due to economic divisions among countries in the region. The rejection of neoliberal policies at the Mar del Plata Summit reflects a shift towards state-based development programs. Latin Americans show dissatisfaction with privatization and support more state solutions for societal problems. Some analysts suggest focusing on bilateral and multilateral agreements instead of the Summit agenda. The fifth Summit of the Americas was held in April 2009 in Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago, with all 34 democratically elected leaders attending. The theme was "Securing our citizens' future by promoting human prosperity, energy security, and environmental sustainability." Cuba was the only country not invited due to its communist government. Some analysts suggest focusing on bilateral and multilateral agreements for free trade instead of the Summit agenda. The Port of Spain Summit in 2009 excluded Cuba due to its communist government. The United States faced isolation in the region with only 58% of Latin Americans having favorable opinions of the country. Venezuela and Bolivia expelled U.S. Ambassadors, and regional bodies like the Rio Group and UNASUR gained more influence while the OAS lost power. President Obama faced policy disagreements and confrontations from some regional leaders at the Summit, including President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela. President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela attended the Summit to defend integration of the Caribbean and Latin America, demanding the US lift its blockade of Cuba and condemning Israel. He also led a meeting of ALBA countries who refused to sign the Summit's Declaration of Commitment. Other regional leaders blamed the US for the global financial crisis and called for a new US policy towards Cuba, leading to low expectations for the Summit. Despite divisions and low expectations for the Summit, some analysts were optimistic due to the Port of Spain Draft Declaration of Commitment, which outlined specific targets and institutions for proposed initiatives. President Obama's attendance was seen as a potential opportunity to improve relations with Latin America. The Summit Implementation Review Group issued a Draft Declaration of Commitment for the Port of Spain Summit, which proposed 65 commitments under six themes. Negotiations continued, resulting in a final Declaration with 96 commitments but less measurable mandates. Some analysts praised the Draft for its focus on implementation, but the final Declaration was criticized as largely meaningless. The final Declaration at the Port of Spain Summit was criticized as largely meaningless, with some countries refusing to sign due to inadequate addressing of key issues. Prime Minister Patrick Manning of Trinidad and Tobago signed on behalf of all participating countries. The Declaration reaffirmed support for past commitments on human prosperity and introduced new goals, such as reducing business start-up times and incorporating non-communicable disease surveillance into national health information. The Declaration at the Port of Spain Summit introduced new goals, including reducing business start-up times, incorporating non-communicable disease surveillance into national health information, and setting targets for education enrollment percentages by specific years. Additionally, commitments were made to develop cleaner and more sustainable energy systems in the Americas. The Declaration at the Port of Spain Summit introduced new goals for economic and social development, environmental stewardship, and public security in the Americas. Countries commit to stabilizing greenhouse gas concentrations, improving environmental planning, and cooperating to combat terrorist and criminal organizations. The Declaration at the Port of Spain Summit focuses on improving capacity to prepare for natural disasters, cooperating to combat terrorist and criminal organizations, supporting regional democratic initiatives, and concluding negotiations on various initiatives. The Declaration at the Port of Spain Summit emphasizes the importance of decentralization, public transparency, and human rights. Reforms to the Summit process include holding Summits of the Americas every three years, providing annual progress reports, and increasing civil society and business group participation. President Obama proposed an "Energy and Climate Partnership of the Americas" to promote energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. President Obama proposed an "Energy and Climate Partnership of the Americas" at the Summit to increase regional cooperation for energy efficiency, renewable energy investment, and greenhouse gas reduction. He also introduced a $100 million "Microfinance Growth Fund for the Western Hemisphere" to combat inequality and promote prosperity. Obama introduced a $100 million "Microfinance Growth Fund for the Western Hemisphere" at the Summit to address finance constraints facing regional MFIs. The fund, a partnership between MIF, OPIC, and IIC, aims to provide stable finance to rebuild lending capacities. Additionally, a $30 million initiative was announced to address security threats in the region. At the Summit, President Obama announced a $30 million initiative to enhance cooperation with Caribbean countries on security issues, including transnational crime and illicit trafficking. He also pledged to reduce U.S. demand for drugs and stop the flow of guns and cash to the region. Analysts believe the Summit may improve U.S. relations with the hemisphere despite some criticism of past policies. The Port of Spain Summit of the Americas resulted in potential improvement in U.S. relations with the hemisphere. President Obama pledged equal partnership and engaged with leaders from various regional organizations. Despite some criticism, his actions were well received in Latin America. President Obama's actions at the Port of Spain Summit of the Americas were well received by leaders in Latin America, marking the beginning of a new era in hemispheric relations. While some concrete steps have been taken to build on the good will generated by the Summit, analysts caution that significant policy differences remain and continued engagement will be crucial for sustaining stronger hemispheric relations.
